hadiths.IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Wail ibn Hujar: I prayed with the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, and when he said 'Allahu Akbar' he would raise his hands, then he would cover himself and take his left side with his right hand and put his hands in his garment. When he wanted to raise his head from ruku', he would raise his hands, then he would prostrate and place his forehead between his hands. When he raised his head from prostration, he would raise his hands until he finished his prayer.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Wail ibn Hujar: A man from Hadramawt and a man from Kindah came to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ. The Hadramawti said: 'O Messenger of Allah, this man has seized land that was in my hand.' The Kindhi said: 'It is in my hand and I cultivate it. He has no right in it.' The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said to the Hadramawti: 'Do you have evidence?' He said: 'No.' He said: 'Then the oath is his.' He said: 'O Prophet of Allah, indeed he is a wicked man and does not care what he swears upon. He does not abstain from anything.' So the Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'There is nothing for you from him except that.' Then he went to swear for him. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: 'Whoever swears falsely on his property to consume it unjustly will meet Allah, the Mighty and the Majestic, while He turns away from him.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Tariq ibn Suwayd al-Hadrami: I said, 'O Messenger of Allah, we are in a land of grapes which we press, and we drink from it.' He said: 'No.' I said: 'But I ask you again.' He said: 'No.' I said: 'O Messenger of Allah, we seek healing with it.' He said: 'It is not a cure, but it is a sickness.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Adi ibn Umayrah al-Hadrami: When the Messenger of Allah ﷺ prostrated, the whiteness of his armpits would be visible. Then when he gave the salutation, he would turn to his right until the whiteness of his cheek would be visible. Then he would give the salutation to his left and turn his face until the whiteness of his left cheek would be visible.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Salamah ibn Nufail al-Hadrami: When Allah granted the Messenger of Allah ﷺ a victory, I came to him and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, the horses have been released from service and weapons have been set aside, and they say the war has laid down its burden and there is no more fighting.' The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: They lied. Now has come the time of fighting. My Ummah will remain dominant over the people. Allah will turn the hearts of a people away and make them a reward and means of sustenance for the believers, until the command of Allah comes at the borders of the Muslim lands in Syria. And the horses are bound with good in their forelocks.

hadiths.english_translation: It was reported that Malik ibn Ubadah was present when Uqbah ibn Amir was narrating from the Prophet ﷺ. Malik ibn Ubadah said: Your companion here is ignorant or lost. Indeed, the Messenger of Allah ﷺ stood as an orator during the Farewell Pilgrimage and said: 'Hold fast to the Quran. You will return to people who desire to hear hadith from me. Whoever understands something from me, let him narrate it. And whoever intentionally attributes to me something I did not say, let him take his seat in the Fire.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Tha'labah al-Khushani: I hope Allah will not strangle me at death as I see you being strangled. One night while he was praying in the depth of the night, he was taken (by death) while in prostration. His daughter saw that her father had died and woke in fright calling for her mother asking where her father was. She said in his place of prayer. She called him but he did not answer. She came to him and found him prostrate. She moved him and he fell to his side, dead.

hadiths.english_translation: It was narrated that Abu Tha'labah sat narrating to the people, and they were discussing hadiths together, mentioning what they feared about the time for their religion. I said: Pardon! Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, says: 'Upon you is [responsibility for] yourselves; those who have gone astray cannot harm you when you have been guided [Quran 5:105].' Abu Tha'labah rebuked me harshly until I wished my mother had not borne me, and I was deeply grieved by it and wanted to leave. But he took my hand and held me until the people dispersed, and none remained except me and him. Abu Tha'labah said to me: Did what I did to you grieve you? I said: Yes, by Allah. He said: We were in a discussion where we feared for our religion, then you came with this verse without bringing its interpretation. We know and command the good and forbid the evil, but a time will come when people will not be commanded to do good and will not be forbidden from doing evil.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Tha'labah al-Khushani: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ prohibited eating of every wild animal with fangs and domesticated donkeys. Abu Awais added to the hadith from al-Zuhri: And from spoils of plunder, seizure by force, and animals killed by suffocation. Salih ibn Abi al-Akhdar mentioned in the hadith: And that pregnant animals be hidden (for protection).

Topics: Ruling on using vessels of People of the Book for cooking and drinking

hadiths.english_translation: He said: And I asked him and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, one of us releases a hunting dog. He said: If you release your trained dog and mention the name of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, and it kills, then eat. If you release your untrained dog and it catches, then put a finishing blow on it. If you release your arrow and mention the name of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, and it kills, then eat.'

chainIssues: Incomplete continuation of a previous hadith - no complete chain provided

potential_issues.issue: Incomplete text - continuation of previous hadith
potential_issues.impact: This is a continuation of the previous hadith without its own complete chain, making it impossible to assess independently.

hadiths.IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok
Topics: Rules for hunting with trained and untrained dogs
